I wanna change the flow a little bit. I like the flow from:
1. Hook
2. Problem
3. Question  And then the mental model. I think the framing of the mental model would be like... And this isn't like you do - I think something gets lost when people start talking about agents in the sense that it's like: "Oh! Like you would just hand off a task to let something else do it completely and you have no control other than like the code review and such?" But this is what every engineering team does when they work with other engineers. There is some engineer less skilled than you are in your certain codebase that you then determine like generally what the task should be and you give it to them and then you can't review it but how it gets done and everything you don't have but there is this implied or explicit way of doing things that standardizes the process of working with them whether that's like compact rules on Git commits to then pass tests you know GitHub actions whatever form of standardization that makes sure things get in there different companies have to then kind of keep things in line. The idea here is that we are trying to transition whatever that you or your company has in terms of standardization protocols into something that can be given to an LLM and acted upon without your effort in the same way any documentation you would have some on a new junior engineer reads they understand what standards that you put forward for them to contribute to the projects that you're working on.

The flow is the mental model, and then the idea will be to go straight into what is a skill? Skills are essentially just an opinionated way of formatting various Markdown files that allow for the agent to self-discover processes and such within the skill for allowing it to then pick up knowledge as it needs to go depending on the task that it's given. It can be a little bit confusing. For this, where Anthropic recently just put this out, and it's been adopted as the general skill structure and whatnot. But it is not that complicated for setting up. The flow would then be:
1. Generally, you'd have a skill that has these top-level who would then show from the blog post and the images that you can find for Anthropic and whatnot.
2. Here is generally how it goes into the prompt.
3. The model can see I have any of these skills in the system, probably be like acquire any skills that you need to before they happen, and it then will go and read these files, and thus you know air quotes it has acquired this skill because it has read this file with this specific knowledge, and that is now within the context window for the agent to operate for the rest of the task.
4. Then we'd go into kind of the skill structure of the file where it's like you know an how this would work.
5. It's like here's the file tree, here are then like you know the references and whatnot.
6. From the main skill, you'd be like for this type of workflow, go to this file, so if it's like okay, I need this skill, okay, I need this specific portion of the skill that reads that, and then now it has you know knows how to do this.
7. This is from a idea of progressive disclosure where only load context when it's needed from various places.\
\
Then the recipe portion would be like what we are trying to do with the skills. It's encoding whatever engineering knowledge that you or your team has in the way that you do things into these skills. So that then whenever you queue up an agent, it can first just more efficiently do flows that you already do. But eventually you trust the agent enough that then you can queue it as a background task. And then all you need to do is review the system and make sure things are right, and you know, stepping farther and farther out of the loop. So that then eventually a lot of tasks that you do in your codebase are performed almost completely by agents.

I'd also like to add to the problem section that I have seen this firsthand of issues where AI just amplifies slop or it amplifies your if you have a good engineer can amplify them greatly, like myself. But in a recent client project I worked on, I ended up having to go and do a lot of front-end work. We had 20 different components in one file, separated by comment blocks. It was just horrendous, and it's not his fault because he was more of a UI engineer that had to write front-end code and he didn't really know what he was doing. But I think this is what everyone has seen: They see the guy or the examples of people that don't know what they're doing use AI, and then it just creates a shitstorm that they have to clean up. People call that coding, but I'm trying to say is don't let this one bad example block your mind from the fact that this is coming and skilled engineers that if you understand what you're doing, AI is a huge force multiplier for yourself.\

This also, I think, should be included in the key takeaway.\

Yes, this is generally a good thing, and I also kind of want to push back somewhere in here about the idea of a 10x engineer. Like being 10 times as much output is a good goal to strive for, but in reality, that's not what you're going to have. It's like aiming for little bits here and there that make you just 10% faster, 5% faster, but these compound over time. You find these little speed-ups in your workflow compounding over months of this, and you will get there, but it's not like there is some magic pill that is instantly going to make you 10 times more powerful. It's like AI does not replace knowledge. We can encode skills and stuff into the Flow that then make the agents able to replicate your work much more efficiently, but this doesn't mean to you know just let the AI handle it completely yet. But it's like you're trying to build towards that future.\
